bibl.note: This document is a letter written to Cherokee agent Colonel Return J. Meigs from Tennessee Governor John Sevier (1796-1801, 1803-1809) on August 5, 1804. The letter states that commissioners from Tennessee and Georgia are to meet on the fifteenth of that month in order to make arrangements for a road connecting the two states to be run through the Cherokee Nation. Sevier asks Colonel Meigs to notify the Indian Chiefs of this meeting and to also let the Georgian commissioners know that the Tennessee commissioners may be late.

div.p: Our Commissioners for the purpose of marking and laying off the road from Tennessee through the Indian Nation into the State of Georgia, are preparing to meet those of from that State at James Vans on the 15th instant

I have deemed it proper to give you this information, in order that you may avail Your self Yourself of any an opportunity of giving the necessary information to the Indian Cheifs Chiefs that they may attend I beg you will be so oblidging obliging as to Write on to Vans, leting letting the Commissioners know of Georgia know, those from Tennessee will soon be on if not on the day, in a very short time afterwards.

I would unk
would be unwilling to impose this trouble on you, had we any opportunity from this Quarter
